We are told that we are being emotional, that our human interaction, relationships and historical links do not matter. These ignorant corporate executives do not understand that sport is about loyalty. It is about passion and emotion. Local institutions such as South Sydney form the fabric which binds people together and makes a cohesive society. A society is not made up of individual pay TV subscribers.

There is overwhelming public support for the people's movement, the members of which are standing together so that South Sydney can stand alone. There is overwhelming contempt for entry criteria which do not include junior development. What sort of sustainable vision is that? We have seen criteria biased against those clubs who have stayed loyal to the Australian Rugby League and have since disappeared or been forced to amalgamate. Rugby league has lost some of its parts, but it cannot survive if it loses its soul.

Whilst money cannot buy respect, News Ltd and the NRL have the opportunity to earn respect by doing the right thing and listening to what the members of the public, the consumers, are saying. The product of rugby league can gain financial value if it can be demonstrated that it remains the people's game. The criterion is retrospective in the short term and does not take into account the cyclical nature of sporting competition.

South Sydney is the world's most successful rugby league team, winning 20 premierships. We have produced 61 internationals and five test captains. The 1925 Rabbitohs remain the only team to go through a season unbeaten. These facts might not matter in foreign corporate boardrooms, but they matter to the kids of Alexandria Street and Eveleigh Street. They matter to the mums and dads who hold cake stalls and raffles so that their kids can buy jumpers and socks and play on the weekend.

Like the working-class people who support them, South Sydney have always paid their way, unlike teams such as Melbourne and Cronulla, which would be insolvent were it not for News Ltd. People from this proud tradition know how to fight in parliament, the streets and in the court. We will fight as the representatives of those who had their hearts broken on 15 October. It is the courageous men and women who shed tears that night at South Sydney Rugby League Club who own the game, not the faceless men who have red and green blood on their hands.

There are a lot of ordinary Australians who long ago tired of those who speak of rationalisation and product. They have been waiting for something to fight for. South Sydney has given them that, and George Piggins has given them that leadership.

talk.start.para: —My colleague the member for Grayndler deserves congratulations for introducing this motion today. It is my pleasure to second it. In doing so, I commend it to the House. I grew up in, live in and represent a district that has always regarded rugby league as the people's game. Our team, South Sydney, the mighty Rabbitohs, has been our people's stake in its game. It has been our property in rugby league, our code of choice.

speech.para: For 91 years, love of league, a passionate commitment to supporting South Sydney, has been the mainstay of our district. It has been a way of life for local people and beyond. Generation has followed generation. They have all invested enormously in our team. They have invested their time, their energy, their money, their leisure, their children's and their children's sporting opportunities. No other emotional commitment could come close to the one put into Souths by legions of supporters for almost a century. We have trained our juniors and attended countless thousands of their games. We have paid our subscriptions and followed our club. We have always paid our way. We have never had much money, that is for sure, but we have never received millions in subsidies from News Ltd to stay afloat, like some of our competitors, who have made the 14-team cut-off.

Souths has been a religion with no shortage of religious zeal. The decision by the NRL to limit future competitions to 14 teams and exclude only Souths from participation in the premier competition next year amounts to the greatest tragedy that could ever befall a league. In excluding Souths, the NRL and its financier, News Ltd, are robbing the supporters of South Sydney of their property and their investment in a sporting code that is nothing short of a way of life.

I am on the public record saying that this decision is all about money. It is about power. It is about greed. It is about commercial interest and business advantage. It is about more money, more power and more greed—indeed, endless greed.

Complaints by News Ltd to my parliamentary leader will not change my view or silence my criticism. The NRL criterion that has been used so ruthlessly to exclude us takes no account of our club's record, which was pointed at to by my colleague the member for Grayndler. No points were given to us for having won 20 premierships—more than any other club. The next best is a mere 13. No points were given for producing 61 international players, which is more than any other club. No points were given for producing five test captains, again more than any other club. No points were given for our having always paid our way while tens of millions of dollars were showered on our competitors, some of whom owe many millions of dollars this day to the same News Ltd.

The NRL criterion amounts to the greatest stacked deck of all time. No points whatsoever were given us for having the best nursery in the code as a result of the magnificent work of South Sydney Junior Rugby League. Souths have always opposed the NRL in this arbitrary decision to cut the competition to 14 teams but, having made that decision, it was incumbent on the NRL to ensure voluntary measures to achieve their objective. Of course, this was not the case. They have now acted to destroy South Sydney, a viable club determined to stand on our own feet just as we have in good times and in bad for the last 91 years. No fair person should condone commercial avarice destroying our place in the code we founded all those years ago.

Should those determined to ruin Souths succeed, like many thousands of rugby league supporters I will finish my association with the code. It is not appropriate to canvass matters currently before the law courts. I do not intend to do so, but I trust that in the months ahead we see justice done and the rights of ordinary people respected. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —In the year before News Ltd started a policy which has almost resulted in the destruction of large segments of the code in Australia, the five top programs watched in Australia were the second State of Origin, the third State of Origin, the second rugby league test against Great Britain, the first State of Origin and the rugby league grand final—all five top programs in Australia were rugby league games. It was reported in the media this year that not one single rugby league game was in the top 30 watched programs this year. Why has that support collapsed? To answer that, you have to understand the game of rugby league.

speech.para: Clearly the people who were responsible for this destruction have never played rugby league or shown an interest in it and they have no love for it. They thought that this was some sort of commercial operation. They do not understand that rugby league is not about money. There are numerous players who have stayed playing for their clubs and passed up enormous amounts of money. They have stayed at home and played for their areas and towns that they have taken pride in over the years.

Kerry Boustead, the greatest ever rugby league winger, resigned from the Cowboys in North Queensland before all these upheavals occurred. I rang him and said, `Kerry, you have a wife and two kids. Do you think this is a smart thing to do?' He said, `Without Arthurson and Quayle, there would have been no Cowboys. It would not exist. They knew the love that North Queensland has for rugby league and the following that the code had in North Queensland. They believed it was the right and proper thing to do to give North Queensland their place in the sun.' Just as Arthurson and Quayle decided that we had a right to our place in the sun, new people have decided that South Sydney and some of the great rugby league traditions that built the code in this nation should be removed and do not deserve and have no right to a place in the sun. That is the reason why these very clever people—who obviously spoke to people who knew nothing about the code when they took these initiatives, which have cost them hundreds of millions of dollars—do not understand.

They could not understand my son, whose grandfather played for Balmain when Balmain was going down in the grand final, simply switching off the television because he could not bear to watch Balmain being hammered. When they buried the great Bob Santamaria, they said that if you thought the man was a cold intellect without passion you should have seen him watching his team on the weekend—I do not know what team he followed. We love those teams and we follow them with great enthusiasm. To take that away from the people of Australia is taking something away from the heart and soul of the nation.

If you think that that is an overstatement: in my old state electorate, of a weekend two teams would travel 1,000 kilometres to play football. For many years of my life I travelled on dirt roads for 1,000 kilometres to play rugby league. We love the game. My uncle was killed playing rugby league. My other uncle spent almost all his life as one of the most active league officials in North Queens land. When people are buried in Cloncurry, they get buried with their team jersey on the coffin. My uncle was buried with a Cloncurry Tigers jersey on his coffin.

When my mother died, it was the coach of the rugby league team who had the invidious task of breaking the news to me. These are things that these people do not understand about Australia and their own country. It is a very sad day for rugby league—a game which I have loved and worked hard for all of my life—to see some of the great institutions of rugby league being destroyed. The member for Kingsford-Smith was dead right when he said that we will not follow rugby league. There are hundreds of thousands of people throughout this country who have made that decision. They will not come back. The game has lost followers throughout Australia's entire length and breadth. These stupid people do not even remotely understand what makes the game tick. If they do not, they are going to lose a lot of money and there will be no-one happier than I if they do. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —They say that politics and sport should not mix. The textbook definition of politics is very simple: who gets what, where and how. For the people who support South Sydney—I cannot count myself as a passionate supporter of that team in particular—the motion today represents what really is at stake, which is the heart of the greatest game of all, the national game, fast becoming an international event of rugby league.

speech.para: As you would know, the rugby league legend started in the areas in which we are talking about today—it has working class origins. Amongst the teams they championed in the Sydney competition were the South Sydney Rabbitohs, named after those who earned a living catching rabbits to try to put a rabbit in the pot and to put some other food on the table. These were the real working class people who wanted to fight against the snobs, the toffs, who preferred to play rugby union, the so-called game of gentlemen played by barbarians—or is it around the other way? Either way, it is a dreadful irony to think that the working class elements that have backed rugby league into what it is today—this multi-squillion dollar enterprise that is run by ratings and newspaper headlines, personality, sponsorship and the concept of what is available on pay television or not—are now going to lose one of their icons.

I do not like talking about class, but at the end of day the we are talking about battlers who need icons, people who need a sense of involvement and importance in getting along to their football match—unfortunately in recent years all too often watching Souths lose. But the spirit has never been lost. We have seen over the years—in recent years in particular—other tough areas, like Balmain, having to go through the indignity of a merger with another club. Balmain will become the Western Tigers next year. I hope they do very well. We are now seeing the gutting of the Rabbitohs by those who have a vested interest in turning a dollar.

My father, when he was younger, played with St George in the under-19s. So I was very much a product of a rugby league household. Having moved to Brisbane some 30 years ago, I watched the Brisbane competition change, and saw the emphasis on the Sunday night football change from watching Souths play Brothers, Valleys, Redcliffe and Wynnum Manly. I cannot help but wonder when I look at this motion before us today—a very good motion the member for Grayndler has put before us—about where the code would be, for instance, if Wynnum Manly had not given Wally Lewis a jersey some years ago, where the code would be if Mal Meninga had not played the way he played for Souths at Davies Park not so many years ago, and where the code would be if the relatively fledgling Ipswich Jets had not given Allan Langer and the Walters brothers the chance, the start, that they got. These guys went on to become the heroes for so many young people in clubs all around my electorate, people who want to be the next Allan Langer or the next Kevvy Walters or whatever.

It is worth noting that even the Broncos in Brisbane, a very powerful club, a fantastic football team in so many ways but so heavily motivated by the dollars, have watched crowds tuning out over recent years as average league fans are turning their back on the bucks. They are offended by so much of what is motivating those who organise rugby league these days, namely the dollars. The punters deserve far more than they are getting.

The punters are copping it in the neck in the crucible of where rugby league was created. We are seeing it now being opened up in countries like Russia. That rugby league is played in Fiji, the UK and France has been long established, but that a nation like Russia is starting to develop its own rugby league teams is amazing. As the member for Grayndler, the member for Kingsford-Smith and the member for Kennedy said, all of this is built on the back of the tradition of the junior clubs involving young kids, giving them the opportunity to play for respect, for decency, for competition—nothing about dollars being the motivating source. It is a great day of shame when we see News Ltd, that powerful organisation with too many fingers in too many pies, destroying an Australian icon before our very eyes.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in support of the motion. On Saturday night, like the member for Kingsford-Smith and the member for Grayndler, I was privileged to attend a dinner, with 1,750 others, to support South Sydney rugby league football team. Another 400 people, who were less fortunate, were still on a waiting list. They would have liked to have attended the dinner but were not able to. In the audience and on stage were very many high profile supporters of the team, such as Alan Jones, Andrew Denton, Ray Martin, Mikey Robbins and Russell Crowe, amongst others. There were many football heroes at the dinner as well. But most of the guests were ordinary people, many of whom would not be used to paying $100 for a dinner, who were turning out to support their club. They were like the 50,000 people who turned out on 10 October to march in support of Souths. They came from all over the state. They were not just Souths supporters but league fans from everywhere.

speech.para: Five thousand people turned out to the South Sydney Leagues Club in Redfern, immediately after the announcement that Souths had been cut from the competition, to share their grief and disbelief at that announcement. The outpouring of emotion and the numbers who marched and who donated to the club's fighting fund show how important this club is to the people of south Sydney. This is a club that meets any sensible criteria for remaining in the NRL competition. It is a club with an unrivalled junior development program. This club, with 160 teams in its juniors competition, provides vital positive role models for inner city kids.

It is not easy being a kid in the inner city. There is not much open space, there is high unemployment, high levels of crime and high levels of drug abuse. Souths players take their responsibility to local kids seriously. They visit schools, hospitals, boys detention centres and jails. They are positive role models, not just of the beneficial effects of physical fitness, which in itself is a valuable message, but of self-respect, teamwork, setting goals and the ability to succeed.

David Leser related a story in his recent Good Weekend article about an ABC producer going to Alexandria Park recently to watch Souths train. The producer was planning a story on Julian O'Neill, but changed her mind when she saw a swarm of kids disrupting the practice to talk to their heroes and get autographs. Instead of ordering the kids off the field, the team set up a duplicate training session for their young fans. This is a club that takes its responsibilities to the community seriously.

It is a club that is financially sound. It does not have a lot of money to throw around but it does not have any debt, either. It has sponsorship for the next five years. Contrast this with Melbourne Storm, which is 70 per cent News Ltd owned and has debts of $14 million and, incidentally, has no junior development program; or Cronulla, which recently needed an $8 million or $9 million injection from News Ltd. Souths is a team that pay their own way, whose shareholders are their fans. It is also a club with a history of contributing to the game.

Others have spoken of the club's history, with 20 premierships—more than any other club—and more international players than any other club. They have spoken of great moments in the team's history, such as when Clive Churchill played a whole game in 1955 with a broken left wrist and when John Sattler played 70 minutes of a grand final with a broken jaw. These men and many others, too many to name today, are part of the history of our area. They are part of the glue that holds the local community together. This history is irreplaceable.

People have lost their banks, some have lost their post offices, some have lost their jobs and are falling behind because they do not have skills which are considered marketable in the brave new world economy that we are being told we have to compete in. Losing their football club is the final sign to these people that they do not matter—big business can walk over communities, and will, if there is a buck in it.
This is what Caroline Jones was referring to in her letter to Lachlan Murdoch published in the Herald. She wrote:
It might help if I explain a few things about Australians, so you can understand why people are saying they hope you rot in hell.

Strong words but, you see, you've trampled on a thing that matters to people. We can hardly find words for it but it's something to do with meaning and a sense of belonging. It's deep and it's real, something we know in our guts . . .

. . . I'm sorry to go against what your father taught you, Lachlan, but there are some things here that money can't buy, though it surprises me to say it. When you do a thing that makes Australian men cry, you know you're on the wrong track.

And the way I see it, what's the point of being the richest kid in the world if people like George Piggins say you're a mongrel. It's a terrible thing to be called. I hope this will make things a bit clearer for you . . .

Souths did not agree to the rationalisation process. They did not agree with the arcane criteria being used to judge which teams stay in the competition—and we all know how easy it is to draw up a set of criteria which will deliver any desired outcome. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I congratulate the member for Grayndler for introducing this motion, the member for Kingsford-Smith who spoke so passionately about South Sydney, the member for Sydney who shares that passion and the members on our side, the member for Moreton and the member for Kennedy. It should be apparent to everybody that this issue transcends party politics. South Sydney supporters are a very special lot of people.

speech.para: The member for Grayndler introduced this motion. He and I would have very little in common politically but as rugby league followers we share a passion for South Sydney and the deep traditions and club spirit shared by all South Sydney supporters and players, past and present. The spirit of South Sydney is hard to describe. They are the battlers in our generation and the heroes of the next generation. As the member for Kingsford-Smith said, they have won 20 premierships. Sometimes it was a long time between drinks. It was a long time between wins for South Sydney.

I commenced my high school years with the Patrician Brothers, Blacktown, as a 12-year-old in 1958. I started playing rugby league at about the same time in the Parramatta junior league for the Richmond club, at the same time playing for Patrician Brothers at Blacktown. At that time, the school at Blacktown had only been open for a couple of years. Our headmaster was Brother Benedict who had played five-eighth for South Sydney before entering the seminary. As kids, we used to travel to Blacktown by train for an hour or so on Saturday mornings to be part of a working bee to sow grass on the school ovals, knee-high in mud. At 2 o'clock, Brother Benedict would hose us down, wash the mud off us, throw us in the back of the old FJ Holden ute and head for Redfern Oval.

The first time I saw Souths play was at Cumberland Oval in 1958, and I had the privilege to watch two of the all-time greats, Clive Churchill and Ian Moir. After that game, which I think Parramatta won, I was a South Sydney supporter for ever. The sight of Churchill cutting down an opponent at grass level even though he was in his twilight years—that was his last year with South Sydney—is permanently etched in my mind. For me and many of my childhood friends, the weekly two-hour train ride from Rich mond to Central and the 30-minute walk to Redfern Oval or the Sydney Cricket Ground or North Sydney Oval or maybe Belmore Oval, depending where Souths were playing, was routine. We celebrated even though Souths might have lost, but that was South Sydney. If the seconds or the thirds won and the others lost, you celebrated just as much as if the firsts got up, because of the spirit.

That was an era when Souths were doing it tough and languishing behind the rich clubs—St George, Western Suburbs, Manly and others. Year after year, Souths faithful would be beaten more often than not, but we all knew that no matter what the score was Souths were great and exciting finishers. They had spirit, they had pride, they were playing for a tradition and one thing we all knew about South Sydney was they would never give in, no matter what stage the game was at. At the same time, Clem Kennedy had a nursery for juniors in the South Sydney district. The ambition of these juniors was not to wear the green and gold of Australia but to wear the green and red of South Sydney.

Rugby league is now dollar driven. Super League spoilt it for rugby league followers for a long time. Now that the Rugby League says, `We don't want you,' I join with other members of this House in saying, `If Souths go, we don't want the NRL.' I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Hansard record would show I have made a number of speeches here about rugby league, all of them supporting the Broncos in my electorate and of which I am proud to say I am a member. But I stand here passionately supporting South's involvement in the National Rugby League and endorsing all of those comments that have been made by earlier speakers.

speech.para: Those involved in administering rugby league would do well to take some notice of the comments that have been made and do well to take some notice of the breadth of view that has been expressed from people from both sides of the chamber. From different geographical areas, metropolitan and provincial, from different states of Australia there is a message being given in the parlia ment today to the administrators of rugby league that they should take heed of. That message, which has been a common thread through the speeches today, is that there is a view in the community today that rugby league stands for more than just watching a spectacle as you might see a good movie show on TV. There is an emotional, historical tie that the people of Australia feel to that game and want to see retained. As much as the big dollars may seek to divert that away, they will not succeed. If they persist, then we will see a recurrence of the problem that occurred when the dispute between the ARL and the Super League occurred originally.

I remember seeing the crowds in Brisbane. In those days the Brisbane Broncos could easily turn out 50,000 or 60,000 to a game. But 50,000 or 60,000 became 20,000, then it became 18,000 and then it became 15,000. We now have the spectacle where Australian rules football will have more people turning out at the Gabba than the Broncos get at ANZ Stadium. They certainly have more paying customers at the Australian rules football than they have at the rugby league in a number of matches. That is the people, the spectators, the public voting with their feet and with their wallets.

What is being told to those administrators today by the parliament is that we share that view and we share those concerns. We want to see that history and heritage that is so much a part of rugby league maintained. Souths epitomise that. The fighting spirit of Souths on the field throughout the decades has been replicated in the campaign that they have waged to stay in the competition. They should be allowed to stay in the competition. This is not a matter for a few shareholders and a couple of large multinational companies to determine. The people and the sporting public have a right to have their voices heard. It is being voiced in parliament today and the administrators should take note.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The honourable member for Brisbane will have leave to continue his remarks when the debate is resumed.

—I rise on a particularly important point of government policy today—that is, the government's approach to coalescence in the aged care sector. I would like to read for the benefit of members in the chamber today some of the quotes which have come from the Productivity Commission inquiry into the government's coalescence initiative. The Productivity Commission's report says on page 81:

speech.para: The Commission does not support the current coalescence proposal. It sees this as being deficient in several important respects.
On page 82 of the Productivity Commission report, it says the government's policy of coalescence `would lead to inappropriate and inequitable outcomes'. On page 84, the Productivity Commission says:

A deficiency in the current coalescence proposal is that the national subsidy rates which would emerge are not linked transparently to the cost of providing a benchmark standard of care. In effect the quality of care could become a residual balancing item. . .

The report requested by this government into aged care coalescence—that is, the idea of having one national rate of subsidy for nursing homes and high care beds in aged care hostels—has been reported on in those terms by the Productivity Commission. It is a very unambiguous, very straightforward and very clear response from the Productivity Commission.

It should be pointed out that this is a body which has not in the past been noted for its great consideration for the plight of people who are disadvantaged. Yet here it is, in black and white, an unambiguous statement from this mostly economic body that the impact of the government's suggested coalescence policy would be absolutely disastrous and that the impact would `lead to inappropriate and inequitable outcomes'. I would have thought it was very clear and very simple—even for the present Minister for Aged Care. It is very straightforward and very easy to understand.

I have spoken to several of the aged care providers in my constituency in relation to this issue. Their response to the government's coalescence proposal is similarly straightforward, easy to understand and unambiguous. I have received a letter from the West Gippsland Healthcare Group, dated 15 November, which states:
The impact of this proposed change will significantly reduce funding to high care (nursing homes) and low care (hostels).

Further on they go into a quantitative analysis of exactly what this proposal would mean for their particular institutions. In their letter they say that the impact for West Gippsland Healthcare Group would be reduced revenue for the Cooinda Lodge nursing home of around $141,000 per annum and reduced revenue for Andrews House, which is a hostel in Trafalgar, of around $3,000 per annum. Obviously that is for the high care beds in that aged care hostel facility.

They go on to do a more substantial analysis of exactly what those simple figures mean to ordinary people—to the families who put their loved ones into those facilities. They work out that the Cooinda Lodge reductions would equate to a loss of around 9,598 hours of care and in Andrews House a loss of about 224 hours of care. The summation at the end of their letter, quoting the Productivity Commission, is that the `current coalescence proposal should not proceed'. This is very clear from the West Gippsland Healthcare Group, an august group that are professionally administered by their very hard-working staff.
In my constituency, Baptist Community Care, which runs the St Hilary's Community Nursing Home in Morwell, states in its letter to me dated 5 November on the same matter:
If coalescence continues, this facility stands to lose $68,021. This does not take into account the CPI dollars that would also be lost.

Baptist Community Care enjoys high repute across all of Victoria. It notes in the letter that it has eight facilities in Victoria which all receive funding for high care. If coalescence continues, Baptist Community Care stands to lose around $520,000 in funding for all of these facilities. Anyone with any commonsense can see that it is completely unfair when this organisation is attempting to achieve best practice in aged care and is focusing, as are many other aged care organisations, on achieving accreditation in its facilities.

Baptist Community Care also point out that they plan on investing around $66 million to upgrade four major facilities. Here is an organisation, a not-for-profit organisation, which is attempting to do the right thing by its residents and by the families who are taking the step of putting their loved ones into the facilities and investing in them to make them as safe and as comfortable as they can possibly be. They state unambiguously that coalescence would be an absolute disaster for their facilities.

Yallambee, in my home town of Traralgon, are another august organisation, a very soundly managed organisation, which enjoys widespread community support. They state unambiguously in their letter to me what the impact will be:

The effect on "Yallambee" services will be an income reduction of almost $100,000. The added reduction due to the inadequate indexation formula currently in use results in a further reduction in income of at least another $20,000 making the total loss of revenue around $120,000 per annum. Alternative calculations show an upper range of almost $200,000 for "Yallambee" services.
That is $200,000 being lost to that organisation. They go on to state in their letter:

At "Yallambee" a reduction of real income of this magnitude will certainly mean a substantial reduction in professional nursing staff by replacement at a significantly lower professional knowledge and skill to the detriment of resident nursing care.
They pose the question, which the minister would do well to listen to and heed:
Would anyone want to see someone close to them receiving less than the optimum care and comfort in their last years?
I think that the question that they pose is particularly poignant and particularly appropriate for the minister to consider.

Last but not least is the plight of the Neerim District Soldiers Memorial Hospital. The gutsy people of Neerim district have striven hard for many years to maintain this important facility, one of the few remaining bush nursing hospitals and aged care facilities left in Victoria. They state in their letter to me of 29 October:
We have been concerned about the effect that this—
that is coalescence—
will have on the financial viability of the Neerim District Nursing Home ever since, and have raised our concerns before through several channels.
Obviously, they have not been listened to. They state in their letter:
We now seek your support to have this ridiculous policy abolished.
And if there was any doubt at all about what their thoughts are in relation to this, they state in their letter:
. . . if the policy of coalescence continues, within four or five years the Federal funding available to our organisation will have dropped by some $96,000 per year.
They state in bold, in italics and underlined:
This drop in funding could not be absorbed and would result in the closure of this facility.

So, whilst this government like to talk the talk about what they do for rural Australia, the result for the good people of Neerim district is that they will close the only bush nursing hospital and aged care facility in that entire district. The result for those people, who have proved enormously resilient for the last five or six years in coming up with innovative fundraising and excellent ways of maintaining that important community facility, is to pull the rug out from underneath them and penalise them for all that guts and hard work which they have shown by introducing this ridiculous, stupid, outdated policy of coalescence, which will mean that the nursing home component of the Neerim District Soldiers Memorial Hospital will have to close. That organisation deserves to be recognised for the hard work which the community has done in rallying behind it and keeping it. The government, instead of pulling the rug from under them, should be supporting them. This government should get behind the Neerim district instead of punishing it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This Tuesday morning in the Parramatta Town Hall, it will be a very great honour for me to welcome the Senior Australian of the Year, Slim Dusty, who will be the guest of honour at an occasion honouring 20 of Parramatta's outstanding seniors. This is part of the government's initiative in relation to the International Year of Older Persons, and I want to congratulate the Minister for Aged Care, who has been doing such an excellent job of highlighting the contribution which the elders of our Australian tribe are making in communities around this country.

speech.para: I have previously mentioned in the House the contributions of three heroines of Parramatta: Betty Schofield, the former matron of Parramatta Hospital; Ensign Esselina van Leusden, who is a permanent fixture on several of the train stations on which I campaign in my electorate, collecting for the Salvation Army—she is a much loved and revered figure, particularly around Toongabbie, Wentworthville and Pendle Hill; and, finally, Betty Holland, who is the President of the Wentworthville Pensioners Association. They are three among the 20 who will be honoured on Tuesday morning, but I want to briefly touch on the contribution of the other 17.

Jack Argent—`Colonel Jack' as he is widely known—is the number one pass holder at Parramatta Leagues Club. The reason for that is that he built the club. In fact, he mortgaged his own home to finance the construction of the club in 1947. He is still the patron of the rugby league Referees Association of New South Wales. He is the President of the Carlingford sub-branch of the Parramatta RSL. His illustrious career involved running in the 440 metres at Wembley Stadium. He played first grade cricket for Cumberland Cricket Club. He was the manager of the rugby league Kangaroo tours between 1959 and 1966. Jack was a candidate for the UAP. He is an unstoppable Parramatta identity, who continues to be a seasoning around the place, bringing a sense of history. He is a bloke who constantly gave more than was expected of him to our community.

Sister Constance Bacha has been one of the leading teaching sisters of Our Lady of Lebanon College in Harris Park for 24 years, since her arrival from Lebanon. She, likewise, is a fragrant personality who uplifts everything she touches, and she is much loved by the staff and particularly by a generation of students at Our Lady of Lebanon.

Elizabeth Boesel is one of those slightly obsessive volunteers whom each of us has in our electorate who just grabs hold of a particular cause and lives and breathes that cause. Everyone who knows Elizabeth Boesel would think of the Galaringi Botanic Reserve in Carlingford. Elizabeth has dedicated her retirement to enhancing that environment for the local residents to have a place of recreation. I want to congratulate her for that contribution.

Joyce Burton is 70 years old but spends four or five days a week as a volunteer with Telopea Neighbour Aid. She also runs what is called the Daisy Club for a group of isolated Dundas residents, providing weekly events and monthly bus trips all over New South Wales. She is doing tremendous work there. It is a great thing to give four or five days a week helping others as a volunteer.

Margaret Dunn was the founder of the Macquarie branch of the National Seniors Association. When she began it in 1995 it was just a humble collection of friends. It now contains over 2,100 members. Margaret is a great advocate of the Paralympics and has sold several hundred tickets already to neighbours and friends and anyone who happens to cross her path. I note that the Minister for Sport and Tourism is at the table. She will be pleased to know that there are these great advocates of our Paralympic athletes spread throughout the community. She is also an active member of the Save the Children Fund and the St Andrews Singers, who go around nursing homes in my electorate providing some encouragement to and fellowship for those residents.

Alan Grey works 35 hours a week at the Parramatta Missions Kitchen, which provides 40,000 meals a year to the homeless. He will be working, for example, providing a meal for 500 people on Christmas Day, as he has done for the last 3½ years, at the Leigh Memorial Church. He works at that kitchen six days a week, and what a great example he has set.

I have previously mentioned in the House the contribution of Betty Holland. Her husband Ted will also be honoured on Tuesday night. He has been the Treasurer of the Wentworthville Pensioners Association for the last 11 years. Ted is not in great health at the moment, but he is a great bloke. Anyone who has lived with Betty for the 50-odd years they have been married probably deserves a medal, but she is likewise a great person. Both of them have spent their retirement blessing the lives of others.

Norm Hossack is a bloke whom I first met campaigning at the Ermington shopping centre where I run a street stall about once every six weeks or so. I found him in the St Vincent de Paul op shop, and he gave me the rounds of the kitchen and raised a lot of local community issues with me. So it should not have surprised me when I later arranged a meeting with the George Kendall River Park Committee—the George Kendall reserve is a big parkland area which is underutilised, undercapitalised and underfunded in my electorate on the Parramatta River—to find that Norm was the chairman of that committee, and he has subsequently lobbied fairly intensely and effectively for that cause. He is again another person whom you find is amongst the relatively small number of people who constantly put up their hands to get the job done.

Gwen Klyen has spent the last 15 years of her life working as a volunteer for the Smith Family Parramatta. The rest of the team there tell me that her assistance in filling gaps, running errands and doing clerical work is like a breath of fresh air. They simply could not deliver the services they do without volunteers like Gwen.

Rita Mitchell was the lady mayoress of Ryde City Council, but she has spent much of her life as a volunteer helping others. She is quite deeply involved in the Henley bowling club, she is an office worker at the Anglican Church in Gladesville and she is the area commandant of St Johns Ambulance—all of that while she is 90 years old. She is the sort of Australian whom the minister, the government and the opposition want to see honoured in this International Year of Older Persons.

Violet Nutt is another person with a multiplicity of volunteering commitments. She has been a member of the North Rocks Soccer Club for 22 years. You will find her at registration days, committee meetings, gala days, grading days, training nights and canteen duty. She is also a member of the 527 and 355 parks management committees. She is an active participant in the Orange Blossom Festival and she is a volunteer drug councillor with Wesley Mission.

Neville Rigg is another volunteer at the Parramatta Mission Kitchen, which is reaching out to the homeless and to those who do fall between the cracks. He is doing a great job. For the last seven years he has been working as a volunteer there three days a week. In spite of some considerable challenges in his own personal circumstances, Neville is still focused on helping others.
I have mentioned Betty Schofield previously in the House, and Hansard records her contribution as a former matron of Parramatta Hospital and much, much more.

Trevor Simpson has spent the last 44 years as an outstanding identity of the Wentworthville community, including being one of the instigators behind the construction of the original Wentworthville community hospital. For the last 33 years he has taught Ju Jitsu to local young people. He has been president of the Ju Jitsu committee of the Wentworthville Leagues Club for the last 17 years. He has been on the Ringrose Park Trust Committee for the last 18 years. He does weekly canteen duty for the Wentworthville Junior Football Club and assists with the reading program at the Wentworthville Public School.

Dave Shakespeare has spent 40 years as a teacher and principal of Parramatta High School. He came down to Canberra as the individual representative of the community of Parramatta as a consequence of his outstanding contribution.

I was with Wendy Tunks just last week at the Toongabbie Third Settlement Festival's annual gala night. She had just come out of hospital. She was still suffering the after-effects of pneumonia, I think, but she was there selling tickets for the hot dogs. She raises $6,000 a year to support drug education in local schools, and she was also responsible for raising in excess of $10,000 to get the community bus for the Wentworthville Area Command.
Joan Wood is a longstanding volunteer, dedicating 27 years of service at the New Children's Hospital at Westmead and she does a lot of their volunteer library administration.
Finally, the CWA Toongabbie is the one organisation being honoured for its contribution. I salute all of them.

talk.start.para: —Today I grieve for the private lives of those who have been, or will perhaps some time in the future be, victims of some of the more sensational and ethically dubious elements of the Australian media. The media are to a certain extent our eyes and ears to the world. The fact that they are housed in this very building, along with the parliament and government, indicates the importance of their role in our democratic society. On the whole, the relationship parliamentarians share with the press gallery is a positive and mutually beneficial one. It is a relationship that is designed to inform the Australian public. Yet at the same time this relationship is a precarious one, as the interests of government, the media and opposition are often divergent. In spite of this, there are certain standards of propriety identified in the journalists' code of conduct which are hopefully protections for dealing with parliamentarians, as with the public. I admit that I have been drawn to making these comments today as a result of a series of events affecting my private life and a difficult Family Court dispute, a situation I suggest known to hundreds of thousands of Australians. I would like to stress that there is cause to raise this case as a cautionary tale that may serve as a warning to policy makers and the public alike.

speech.para: In particular, there are two facets in the practice of some media reportage of the private lives of public figures that I would like to draw to the attention of this House. It is not unheard of for a public figure such as a politician to be plunged into the media spotlight in less than ideal circumstances. Of course, there are valid reasons for subjecting someone's character to public scrutiny if it is believed that it may impact on his or her ability to carry out their job. But surely the scrutiny must be backed by substantiated evidence and a demonstrable public interest. American presidential candidate Bill Bradley recently stated:

The public has a right to know if I'm a crook. But that's where it should stop. Unless the media has substantiated evidence of flaws in my character that may negatively impact on my ability to fulfil my duties as a politician then they should butt out.

Senator Bradley was emphasising that parliamentarians are people too. Just like other members of the public, they have some right to privacy. A line must be drawn that will quarantine the media from reporting on the private lives of the public, including public figures, and this line should be honoured.

This brings me to my second point, and that is to emphasise the distinction between on the one hand the insidious practice of `never letting the facts get in the way of a good story' and on the other hand reporting thoroughly researched issues of public interest. There is a widespread public sentiment that underlines why there are such high ratings for, and why we find so funny, programs such as Frontline. Unfortunately, the attraction of sensationalised stories seems in a few cases to override the obligations of the media to the public in reporting of the facts. Worse still, a few in the electronic media hype unproven stories or events with an image or a comment, as was the case in my recently widely publicised run-in with the Seven Network. For some people, this seems to be accepted practice.

In my case, the journalist concerned latched onto and reported the existence of an interim order that had been taken out against me only after there had been consent orders which I had applied for in the Family Court. For the record, the term `interim' means that the information supplied by the complainant is yet to be disputed or rebutted by the person mentioned in that order—that person being me. Incredibly, these facts were completely ignored by the journalist and the story went to air on national television, even though it was based on information based on those unsubstantiated orders. For the record, I would like to stress that the interim order was later struck out by a magistrate. The channel was informed of all the facts before both broadcasts. On the second occasion they even dropped the earlier qualifications.

Needless to say, this journalist's actions have had the most profound effect on the lives of my family and me, and particularly on my children, in the middle of this difficult Family Court problem. Never have I understood so well Arthur Miller's famous play The Crucible, which portrays the Salem witch trials—trial by allegation. I know and understand so well the ugliness of being accused of being guilty without trial. It is well known in this House that I sued the Seven Network and the individual responsible for this story and I won. Network 7 have apologised unconditionally in open court and have been ordered to pay very large legal costs.

At present there is too little to stop this sort of damage from being inflicted on anyone. If it can happen to me, a resourceful parliamentarian, it can happen to anyone. Indeed, in most cases it would be much harder for ordinary members of the public to fight an injustice of this magnitude. On the other hand, other elements of the media, such as a number of recent programs on A Current Affair, have highlighted the exponential granting of interim orders. A Current Affair argues that easily granted interim orders are used by some people as a form of harassment.

We rely on the media to report in good faith and to convey as accurate a picture as possible of current affairs. Most do a good job. We, as individuals paid from the public purse, must be accountable. But the use of private problems of public figures for salacious purposes harms public debate. If Mr Stokes, Mr Murdoch and Mr Packer wonder where the bipartisan support for privacy legislation in this House comes from, they need look no further than events like this case, where hundreds, if not thousands, of people are aware of the outcome, and indeed the injustice perpetrated by the Seven Network.

This was not an easy matter to try and address in a dispassionate manner. Obviously I may be subject to further attacks from the journalist concerned because I took the difficult decision to take on him and his powerful network in court. My colleagues, my constituents and my family know that I will never resile from putting the public good. Yes, this matter does affect me. In my view, though, it had to be said. The public policy issues remain. The apology and these remarks close this chapter as far as I am concerned.

talk.start.para: —Last Thursday I had the opportunity to help launch the project Kids and Domestic Violence, the aim of which is to improve community and professional awareness of how to repair the damage done to children by domestic violence. This project is being funded under the auspices of Partnerships Against Domestic Violence, which has been coordinated by Senator Jocelyn Newman in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I was very fortunate to represent the minister at the Convention Centre in Brisbane at that particular launch. I must commend the Queensland government on the funding that we provided to them in launching these very good manuals on domestic violence.

speech.para: At that particular conference there were a number of organisations represented, including the Rural and Remote Domestic Violence Initiative, the Council of Children, Young Working Women's Project, Indigenous Family Relationships pilot project, Relationship Support Services for Men, and Domestic Violence and Pregnancy. There were a number of Torres Strait Islander domestic violence community education groups, as well as a number from Cape York, and many representatives from all over Australia. Some 200 people were at the conference and it was great to see many of these issues being addressed, particularly in relation to young people, men's programs and indigenous communities.

Domestic violence is a crime that does horrific emotional and psychological damage to victims, and it is deeply tragic that the effects can be passed on to the next generation. As such, it is critically important that greater effort be given to preventing domestic violence. There is a growing body of evidence of the harm to children who witness domestic violence. Some of these symptoms are fear, isolation, self-blame and anxiety. Children may respond by withdrawing, exhibiting behavioural problems, developing physical and mental illnesses and having great difficulty in resolving conflict and forming healthy, stable relationships.

Women's Safety Australia found that 46 per cent of women who had experienced violence by a previous partner and 38 per cent of women experiencing violence by a current partner said that they had children who witnessed the violence. Studies in Australia and the USA indicate that this is likely to be an underestimate and that children are often far more aware of violence in their home than parents realise. In my own electorate of Petrie some 500 cases of domestic violence are reported every year. At the conference I heard the minister, Anna Bligh, report some 12,000 cases in Queensland alone. It does not take much to realise that some 30,000 children in Queensland each year experience domestic violence.

The cornerstone of the government's commitment to preventing domestic violence is a $50 million contribution to establishing the Partnerships Against Domestic Violence project. Senator Newman's office recently announced details of initiatives to be undertaken, with an additional $25 million committed by the Commonwealth to the partnerships program in the 1999-2000 budget. One of the key priority areas is children at risk, and the partnerships program is planning a major national forum on children in April next year. This will help focus on what has been learned thus far and what the next steps should be in carrying forward the work for children at risk.

The seminars of Partnerships Against Domestic Violence highlight the effort that the government is making in seeking to combat this evil. The strong leadership taken by the Commonwealth government is reflected in the fostering of a broad alliance of partnerships throughout the community. This includes across all levels of government, with business, non-government organisations, community groups, individuals, families, churches and welfare groups also involved. The fruit of these collaborative efforts is reflected in seminars like the Kids and Domestic Violence project in Queensland. This project exemplifies what the partnerships program is all about. It is an innovative approach to developing better and earlier intervention and prevention. The project took a national focus and has a national application.

The outcome of this project will address a major gap in our current knowledge on what is effective practice when dealing with children affected by domestic violence. The exciting thing is that the resources from the Kids and Domestic Violence project could potentially influence the development of new approaches across the country. I am very pleased to see that Queensland is leading the way in this particular area. The initiative of the government is to be commended. With hundreds of millions of dollars spent each year dealing with the effects of domestic violence, it is timely that the goals of early intervention and prevention have received the attention they deserve. I wish to give particular credit to Senator Newman for her enthusiasm and commitment to the partnerships program.

Indigenous participants are also very important. Recently, Senator Herron conducted a roundtable on indigenous family violence, which was held in Brisbane in July this year. The conference looked at many ways of addressing this extremely serious issue and how it could be addressed more effectively. The effects on children of the levels of family violence in indigenous communities were high on their list of concerns. There needs to be assistance with the strengthening of community efforts to address family violence. Senator Newman has also announced a community grants program as a way of assisting communities which are searching for or finding effective ways of tackling family violence, including the damage done to children.

Work with perpetrators will build on the outcomes of the national forum on perpetrators, convened earlier this year by the Commonwealth minister for justice, Senator Vanstone. The Commonwealth is looking at ways to assist the service provision role of the states and territories through funding initiatives in areas such as standards and evaluation. Work in these four areas will continue the close collaborative work between the Commonwealth and the states and territories that has characterised the partnerships program to date. This will include bringing together working groups of relevant state and territory officials and stakeholders from the community to develop and implement new initiatives.

The minister has also invited states and territories to nominate relevant experts for a working group on perpetrators, and this group will be requesting experts from state and territory governments and communities to form working groups around other key areas of new work. The particular events of last week, at which I had the pleasure of representing the minister, increase this awareness, particularly for front-line workers but also for policy makers and planners. A number of innovative partnership projects are being implemented at the moment at the national, state, territory and Commonwealth levels.

Showcasing recognises the need to promote a much broader understanding of key issues and new information in the domestic violence field for everyone concerned with responding to those affected by domestic violence. These collaborative efforts are very good. One of the most important things that this workshop highlighted was the need to work with small groups of children, particularly to define violence and the responsibility for violence, to express feelings, including anger, to improve communication and other skills, to increase self-awareness, to develop safety plans and a social support network, to learn and to have a positive experience. It is particularly important that these particular group activities are focused on in the workshops and in the standards and manuals developed.

When dealing with children, it is important to work on a particular theme. Worksheets, drawing, craft, cooking, sharing stories, physical activities, role-play, relaxation and informal social time, review and closure were very important. Children are unable to speak about these experiences, and they are unable to speak about power and control in relationships or to learn conflict resolution strategies, so it was important that they address them through drawings—and that was a particularly useful part of this program.

It is important that we do look further, and there is so much work yet to be done in this particular area. I know that this government has always had a strong commitment to working with children and providing a much stronger future for the next generation, and nowhere is this more important than in helping innocent children who have suffered such enormous damage to overcome the trials associated with domestic violence. It is important that they get a chance to have a balanced and fulfilling life.

While it is naive to assume that, just because of this initiative, domestic violence will suddenly disappear, I am sure that this project will reduce the incidence of domestic violence as strategies for early intervention and prevention are developed. The Partnerships Against Domestic Violence program will mean that we can look forward to the new century with hope. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
Diesel Fuel: Environmental and Health Impacts

talk.start.para: —In this grievance debate today, I wish to speak about two issues which are dear to my heart: the Australian Broadcasting Corporation—the ABC—and diesel fuel. In relation to the ABC I wish to express my grave concerns about recent events in the Australian media—in particular the revelations before the Australian Broadcasting Authority inquiry into cash for comments and the appointment of a new managing director at the ABC.

speech.para: As I mentioned in the House on 9 August, I am a supporter of the ABC. Its role and culture are vital. Its services in news and current affairs, drama, documentary, comedy, information, entertainment, children's programming, music and orchestral performance are of a high quality. Under the Howard government there has been a determined effort to marginalise the ABC through funding constraints and through the government's action in making the ABC sell up property to fund conversion to digital broadcasting rather than use the money to retire debt and make more programs.

If there is any incident in recent months which has demonstrated the continuing need for a non-commercial ABC, it is the cash for comments inquiry currently being conducted by the ABA. The ABC's Media Watch program exposed the details of a contract between the Australian Bankers Association and interests associated with 2UE announcer John Laws, and it can now be seen that there has been no effective regulation of the commercial broadcast industry under the ABA. Media Watch demonstrated yet again the need for an independent ABC, uninfluenced by vested interests. What did the ABA ever do within its existing powers to bring 2UE to account—particularly after Media Watch first raised the cash for comments issue in 1994? Without this independent ABC program, the potential for corruption of standards and breaches of so-called codes of conduct by the broadcasters would not have been confronted.

Now I have noticed, as I am sure all honourable members have, the ABC board's appointment of Mr Jonathan Shier as the next Managing Director of the ABC. Mr Shier has an impressive record as a commercial free-to-air and pay television broadcast manager and senior executive in Europe and the United Kingdom. In the news conference held at the time of his appointment, he encouragingly reaffirmed the view that the ABC should not run advertising on its radio and television networks. But what alarmed me was his apparent acceptance of the notion that the ABC board might want to look at running advertisements on ABC online Internet services. We have already had one board member, Michael Kroger, suggest that the ABC should sell up to half of its Internet services, valued at $500 million. Fortunately, the current board has rejected this idea.

I want to put on record my opposition to the ABC selling advertising on its Internet services. I do not care what the ABC does or what any other so-called public broadcaster elsewhere may or may not do. The moment the ABC is forced to seek commercial revenues to sustain its services, the very nature and focus of the ABC will change. The consequences of an ABC in active pursuit of advertising dollars are clear. Instead of applying its independence through its news, current affairs and other programming to bring us innovative, quality work, the ABC will change to making programs to enhance revenues. It will be placed in competition for commercial revenues from other online services.

I am asking the Howard government, and particularly the minister for communications, whether this issue can be put to rest immediately or whether those of us who support a non-commercial ABC have to take up the cudgels in defence. The ABC is about to embark on triennial funding negotiations with the federal government. Its future in the digital era is by no means secure. It is waiting to see government decisions on multichannelling of its television services to enhance regional services. It is waiting to see if the government will advance the necessary funding to enable this enhancement. The ABC is waiting to see if it will be able to enhance services through datacasting—text, audio and vision—which will build on the ABC's established strengths. The ABC is always waiting, it seems to me.

This government has demonstrated its malevolence towards this great national institution; it prefers to suck up to the media barons—Kerry and James Packer in particular. The government must guarantee the ABC's future into the digital era and fund it adequately to help it meet its plans for enhanced services.

It is time the government got the funding hooks out of the ABC. If the new managing director pursues commercial revenues as an alternative to government funding, it will be a clear signal to me and to other observers that the government expects and wants this direction for the national broadcaster. I call on the government, particularly as the current ABC expressly prohibits advertising on ABC radio and television, to declare that it does not want advertising on ABC online services. A failure to do so will only signal the government's agenda to commercialise, and therefore destroy, public broadcasting in Australia.

I turn now to diesel fuel. There is a growing tendency in this term of government to not respond to parliamentary representations and hence the will of the public interest. In particular, I refer to my question on notice No. 913—which appeared in this House's Notice Paper on 20 September 1999—which was on an issue of critical importance to my constituency: diesel fuel and its associated environmental and health risks. This question was put to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the honourable John Anderson.

The decision of the federal government—and of the Australian Democrats—to reduce the excise on diesel fuel has ignored a mass of evidence that demonstrates diesel emissions are exposing the Australian population to serious environmental and health risks. This evidence is chiefly found in three authoritative documents: (1) the World Health Organisation Environmental Health Criteria series; (2) the Scientific Review Panel of California Air Resources Board; and, most importantly, (3) the European Charter on Transport, Environment and Health of the European Ministers of Environment and Health.

A response from the minister was received at the Table Office on 10 November 1999—some six weeks after the question was tabled. To me, the response says, `I'm not prepared to authorise the time and resources required to prepare responses to this question.' It took the minister six weeks to say that he was not prepared to authorise the time and resources to prepare a response to one question. In doing so, the minister has wasted my constituent's time, he has wasted my time and he is wasting the time of this House. In the minister's written response we see his laconic contempt for this issue and the parliamentary process. It does not take six weeks to reach such a conclusion. This response lacks intellectual content. It is a flight of fancy. He could have formed this opinion within a mere moment. No, he chose to wait and delay the issue and then publicly admit that he is not prepared to respond to the question at all.

Like every member of this House, I represent my constituents. In every electorate there is a unique cross-section of people from all walks of life. In the electorate of Lowe, we are blessed to have a number of meritorious persons who demonstrate particular aptitude and knowledge in the topic of diesel fuel environmental impacts. In this instance, my constituency comprises persons with a particular interest in this field. Hence my question reflects a higher knowledge on the issues surrounding diesel fuel. The minister's refusal to respond sends an arrogant message of lack of interest to me and hence to the constituents. Further, it is a serious breach of the honour system we rely upon for the good working of representative democracy.

This is parliament; it is not a cafe chat. Standing order 144 places responsibilities on all members to ask meaningful and relevant questions. Once those questions are properly put, there is an expectation that all reasonable attempts will be made to respond to those questions. Standing order 150 requires every member of this House to respond within 60 days. To simply refuse to respond to a question on notice, properly put, is highly capricious at its worst, especially on an issue as critical as environmental harm and health effects.

The minister refers to two other documents in his response: (1) `Measures for a Better Environment' of 28 May 1999 and (2) the minister's second reading speech for the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999. I have read these documents. They take the reader nowhere in addressing the question put to him. So here we have a response from the minister—the Deputy Prime Minister—that, first, refuses to respond at all and, second, cites irrelevant material.

We are all under pressure in this House. The minister, by virtue of his high office, receives additional staff and resources in order to perform his tasks as a minister. There can be no function more immediate to the role of a minister than his performance in this House, including the prompt and efficient answering of questions on notice. Where is there a more relevant and proper mechanism for the presentation of questions to a minister than through the official channels of questions on notice through this House? If there is one channel through which a minister should answer questions, then surely it is in this chamber. Not so, it seems. The minister is above parliamentary process. He considers the parliamentary process to be too great a strain on his resources, and chooses not to respond to his parliamentary tasks in this House.

I promise that this matter will not stop here. What the minister fails to appreciate is that refusal to answer carries with it its own consequences. His response is a matter of public record. He is not writing me a `dear John' letter. I have supplied his response to leading academics and the media. The world at large can see his response and form their own opinion. Let this be a warning to the minister—who, I add, is Deputy Prime Minister—that responsible government means just that: responding to proper representations from the constituency. This means giving all a fair go and responding to the best of his ability on every representation properly put before this House.

talk.start.para: —Today I rise to speak on two matters that concern constituents in my electorate of Gilmore, which includes the New South Wales South Coast, Kiama and the Southern Highlands. The first is illegal immigrants and the second is the National Cadet Scheme.

speech.para: Many people have expressed concern to me about the growing number of boat people arriving in Australia. Of course, the size of Australia and its sparse coastal population, except on the eastern side, make it easy to get in and difficult to detect new arrivals. Having said that, it is not meant as an excuse, as I totally agree that something needs to be done. However, the issue is not easily addressed, given our nation's commitment to a fair go for all. As Australians we fight hard to uphold the right of appeal in all administrative and legal processes. How then do we deny those rights to some people? How do we close that door without breaking with the spirit of this country?

It is not simply a case of `turn them around and send them back', as many in the community are urging. Under the 1951 Geneva convention and the 1967 protocol, Australia has obligations to assess any claim for protection that may be made by an illegal immigrant. In my opinion, there is a correct way to come to Australia, and the processes are in place to determine those people most in need of refuge. Yet we must have that ability to hold back the people who want to queue jump regardless of others' needs. Remember: someone is getting very wealthy through trading in human lives and hopes. Someone is making a lot of money out of people's grief, and that to me is barbaric and needs to be dealt the severest of penalties. As a government we are working with overseas agencies to catch these traders in human flesh and to charge them with these serious crimes against humanity.

Illegal immigrants are simply pushing in—queue jumping ahead of people whom we have determined are in far greater need. This simply is not fair. In my opinion, they should be sent to the back of the line. Therefore, because of this surge, I am asking everyone to watch our coastline, to recruit more volunteer coast watchers and to be more alert to suspicious circumstances. We need every available pair of eyes watching for signs of movement or habitation that seems incongruous. It is the obligation of all Australians to assist with the search for illegal immigrants. No government can do it all. The coastline and the country inside its boundaries are too big and too sparsely populated for any government to see everything.

It has not been our way to have authorities set up surveillance systems to watch Australians in their daily lives. Similarly, I do not want to take away the heritage of our volunteer agencies. They have provided a magnificent coastal patrol service to the more populated areas. Yet just look at how close a recent boatload of illegal immigrants got to the beaches in my electorate. That boat had been tracked for several weeks, and the Australian Federal Police on the Colin Woods boat were used to challenge the ship and turn it away from our shores. If they had ignored that challenge and run aground on one of our beaches, I am not sure that too many people would have noticed. So I am asking for people to rally in a sense of community spirit to give public support to keeping illegal immigrants out of our country so that those deemed most needy can come to our safe havens. I am also asking people in my electorate of Gilmore to suggest solutions, as many heads are better than one. Today in my office there will be a survey to see what people actually think and to enable them to give their opinions.

I believe that the Australian people realise that the government cannot do this on its own. Australia works closely with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to admit 12,000 of the neediest refugees a year—more per capita than any other developed country in the world. Why should these others, who could afford to pay more money to the flesh dealers than a plane ticket would cost, be allowed to push in? Every onshore queue jumper takes away one of the places available for a UNHCR-assessed refugee languishing in refugee camps offshore. I implore everyone on the coast, especially in the electorate of Gilmore, to be on the lookout. Do not allow our country to be entered by people who provide no skills or resources to our nation when we have many others waiting their turn to become Australian citizens.

I now turn to my second topic—cadets and a national cadet program. I recently went to Perth to attend a conference looking at the Western Australian cadet program and how it might be translated into a national cadet program. At that conference, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr David Kemp, announced funding to set up a group to establish the kind of framework such a program would need and to run some pilot schemes. This program has been something that I have been waiting to see for many years. Therefore, in my role as chair of the Coalition Defence and Veterans' Affairs Committee, I was involved over the last few months in obtaining cabinet's backing for this program. I am interested in running one of those pilot schemes in Gilmore.

To this end, I ran the first of several forums in my electorate to test local reaction to the scheme. This forum coincided with a visit to the area by Senator Eric Abetz who, in his role as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, has responsibility for cadets. Coordinators of existing military cadet units, teachers, parents, young people and youth workers attended the forum. All were supportive of a national cadet program.

One of the strengths of the cadet program is its great flexibility. It can be run in school hours or out of school hours, on school grounds or off them. It can be attached to any other organisation and it is designed to run in conjunction with the cadet units already in existence. The point of the program is to provide choice. Some young people may want to join something exciting, fun and organised but are not interested in things of a military nature. However, they could be interested in joining bushranger cadets run by the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Department of Land and Water Conservation or emergency services cadets run by the Rural Fire Service, SES, and the Volunteer Rescue Association.

With the flexibility we would build into the eventual program, it should be entirely possible to offer the cadet program as one of the choices under the mutual obligation system. To explain, when young people request financial assistance from Centrelink, they can no longer expect to receive the money and do absolutely nothing. Currently, they must study, be in training, work for a community based organisation or actively seek work. In the future, they could also be offered a certain number of hours per week in a cadet unit of their choice. Whilst schools are the obvious place to start for recruitment, there is nothing to prevent school-age people who are not attending school for whatever reasons from also joining cadets.

A national cadet program would offer discipline, nationally accredited and portable training, leadership and team building skills, avenues for breaking current stereotypes for young people in the community, and the ability to gain rites of passage into our society in the event there is no work. In fact, it may be that all the participants in the Work for the Dole program could instruct cadets if they had those special skills. Similarly, our older Australians, many of whom are seeking avenues for sharing their knowledge, skills and experience, could also provide instruction and guidance on the program.

Governments must also be responsible and provide trained and accredited instructors who have had their backgrounds thoroughly checked to ensure the safety of our young people. It is also incumbent on us as a government, if we are really serious about it, to resource the program properly. The Western Australian experience is that in many of the small towns and villages where a cadet unit has been established the youth crime rate has dropped by up to 35 per cent. This alone is justification for trialling this program.

When you consider that it costs conservatively between $70,000 and $80,000 to detain a young person under the juvenile justice system, the three tiers of government should be working hard together to make sure that this program is successful. In Western Australia, the cadet program provides a one-off establishment grant of $5,000 to the group supporting the cadet unit and $450 per cadet annually to cover uniforms and other costs. Even if we doubled that amount, it would still be a huge saving to all governments if just a few hundred young people were not in trouble with the law as a result, thereby offering the peace of mind to older Australians that they can safely walk the streets at night.
