(2) It is envisaged that all institutions undertaking research and research training including Bond University and the University of Notre Dame Australia, would be eligible to receive block funding on the condition that they furnish an acceptable Research and Research Training Management Plan and are listed on the register of bodies for the Australian Qualifications Framework. There is no intention that this be extended to other public or private research organisations.

(3) Under the Green Paper proposals, the differential between science and arts PhDs would be maintained, funded through the Institutional Grants Scheme, until studies have been completed in consultation with the sector which identify the relative costs of research training in different disciplines. This is foreshadowed in the Green Paper. It should be noted that postgraduate research students in receipt of an Australian Postgraduate Research Student Scholarship will not be required to pay HECS under the new arrangements.
(4) Based on recent international comparisons carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Australia ranks fifth overall in terms of government sector R&D expenditure and third in terms of

higher education sector R&D expenditure. On both measures, Australia ranks higher than each of the four countries for which comparisons are sought (see table attached.) It is not possible to provide information specifically on basic research.

entry.para: Higher education R&D as % of GDP

answer.para: There is no reduction in funding projected for the Australian Research Council. The reforms outlined in the Green Paper for funding to the Australian Research Council, provide that the ARC's peer-reviewed funding programs will increase from $234 million in 2000 to over $283 million the following year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Is a lease held by the City of Kingston over 1.554 hectares of parkland in Levanto Street, Mentone, Victoria, owned by his Department, due to expire in November 2000.
(2) Is it a fact that the land, Chiquita Reserve, is used by local residents for recreation purposes and includes a scout hall.

(3) Did his Department advise the City of Kingston on 4 May 1998 that it intends to dispose of the property at the expiration of Council's lease and that the City would be offered first right of refusal on the property.

(4) Did the Council write to his Department on 2 September 1998 advising that Council would be unable to raise the estimated $2.5m required for the purchase and requesting the transfer of ownership to Council at the expiration of the lease so that the land may continue to be used as recreation space.
(5) Has the Council's letter remained unanswered for thirteen months; if so, why.
(6) Will he direct his Department to transfer ownership of the parkland to the City of Kingston Council for the continued recreational use of Mentone residents.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. There is a 25 year revenue lease over this property that will expire on 29 November 2000.
(2) Yes, the land is open to use by local residents. A small portion of the property is sub-leased by the Council to the Mentone Scout Group, formerly the 13th Mordialloc Scout Group.

(3) Yes. The Department also advised that should Council not be interested in acquiring the property, it would be offered for sale on the open market in line with the Commonwealth policy on the disposal of surplus property.
(4) Yes, although there was no mention of the estimated value of the property.

(5) and (6) In view of the expiry date for the lease of 29 November 2000, a response to the Council was not provided until Defence had considered a possible strategy for this property. Notwithstanding, Defence should have acknowledged the letter. On 15 September 1999, Defence wrote to Council in order to commence discussions on the future of the property. A meeting was held subsequently between Defence and Council officers on 15 October 1999. Defence agreed to commission a valuation of the property to provide to Council for its consideration. The meeting also discussed the framework in which Defence has to work in relation to the disposal of surplus Commonwealth property.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 30 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Does his departmental publication Exports of Primary and Manufactured Products, Australia, 1998, state that exports of elaborately transformed manufactures (Australian produce) in 1998 were $15 689 million.
(2) Is it a fact that this represents an $868 million or 5.2 per cent fall on the 1997 figure.
(3) When did this series last show a fall in these exports, in dollar terms.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) 1998 was the first time a fall was recorded in this series since compilation began in 1978. The fall was mainly the result of the economic situation in East Asia, as foreshadowed early this year in the Government's Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement, 1999. East Asia accounted for 39 per cent of our exports of ETMs in 1997, and in 1998 was experiencing its worst ever economic setback. The contraction in exports to East Asia more than offset strong gains in ETMs exports to other markets in 1998, such as the US, Canada, the United Arab Emirates, the UK and Germany.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Does the Danish Government maintain an Embassy in Australia; if so, (a) where, (b) when was it opened and (c) does it maintain other diplomatic posts or missions in Australia.

(2) Will he make a public statement on the location of (a) the Australian Embassy in Denmark and (b) the residence of the Australian Ambassador to Denmark, including all costs associated with the (i) selection, (ii) purchase or (iii) renting of the appropriate premises; if not, why not.

(3) Is he able to say whether (a) Australian exports to Denmark have reached the lowest point since 1995 and (b) Australia's trade imbalance with Denmark has grown to $381 651 million in 1998-99; if so, (i) why does he say in his answer to question No. 847, part 4 (b) that the decision to re-open Australia's Embassy in Denmark was made in the light of Australia's growing trade interests with that country and (ii) are such bad trade figures related to Australia's decision to close its Embassy in Denmark; if so, will he take action to station Austrade staff at the new Australian embassy; if not, why not.

(4) What was the full cost to the Commonwealth, including all staff redundancy payments and costs associated with re-locating and transporting Australian diplomatic staff, of closing the Australian Embassy to Denmark and the associated residence of the Australian Ambassador in May 1997.
(5) Can he provide a breakdown of the costs referred to in part (4).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(1) (a) Denmark maintains an Embassy in Canberra.
(1) (b) The Danish Embassy was first opened in Canberra in 1967.
(1) (c) Yes. There is a Danish Consulate-General in Sydney, an honorary Consulate
General in Melbourne and honorary Consulates in Hobart, Brisbane, Adelaide and Fremantle.
(2) These details can and will be made available after the post has been opened and when the selection of premises has been made.
(3) (a) Australian exports to Denmark of $77.49 million in 1998-99 were at their lowest level since 1993- 94.
(3) (b) The deficit in trade with Denmark was $381.615 million in 1998—99.

(3) (b) (i) A judgement on the prospects for trade was just one of the factors, albeit an important one, underlying the decision to re-open. Exports to Denmark reached their highest level—$221 million—in 1998. Exports were boosted by the sale of two fast ferries in that year. While no ferry sales occurred in 1998—99, Australian fast ferry companies remain active in the market and overall, we remain optimistic about future export growth, including in other areas.
(3) (b) (ii) No. It is normal for trade figures to fluctuate. Austrade already has an office in Copenhagen, staffed by a Senior Trade Commissioner and three other full time staff.

(4) As a result of the closure, there was a net saving in running costs incurred by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of A$1.3 million in the financial year 1997/98. Savings of A$5,501,189 also accrued to the Overseas Property Group (OPG) in the financial year 1996/97, achieved largely through the sale of the Commonwealth-owned Chancery and the Ambassador's residence. Local staff redundancy payments cost A$315,000, while costs of removals and airfares for relocating Australian-based employees totalled A$66,153.
(5) See (4) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 30 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to parts 7 and 11(b) of question No. 847, is he able to say whether, following the Howard Government's decision to close the Australian Embassy in Denmark in May 1997, the Commonwealth-owned (a) building which housed the embassy and (b) Ambassador's residence were sold after the mission was closed; if so, for what price were they sold, in Australian dollars.

(2) If the building and residence were not sold, have they been rented throughout the period since the mission was closed; if so, (a) by whom, and (b) for what annual rent, in Australian dollars; if not, why not.

(3) What was the full cost to the Commonwealth, including all staff redundancy payments and costs associated with re-locating and transporting Australian diplomatic staff, of closing the Australian Embassy to Denmark and the associated residence of the Australian Ambassador in May 1997.
(4) Can the Minister provide a breakdown of these costs referred to in part (3).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, both properties were sold. The Embassy sold in September 1997 for AUD $2.92 million, and the Head of Mission residence was sold in August 1997 for AUD $1.55 million.
(2) Refer to answer (1) above.
(3) This matter does not fall within my portfolio responsibilities.
(4) This matter does not fall within my portfolio responsibilities.

subdebateinfo.title: East Timor: Australian Defence Force Deployment
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 973)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 11 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Did the Minister for Defence in an answer to a question without notice (Hansard , 23 September 1999, page 7870) following the fist week of operations advise that Australia had deployed 2468 ADF personnel to East Timor, another 987 person nel were serving on ships and that 282 personnel were serving from coalition partners.
(2) On the basis of the answer, is Australia currently providing 92.5% of the INTERFET forces.
(3) What will be the percentage of Australian forces deployed in East Timor when coalition partners have fulfilled their promised commitments.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) No. Increasing international troop contributions have reduced the proportion of Australian forces in INTERFET. As at 19 October, the percentage of foreign forces was 27.5%.
(3) Not all INTERFET coalition partners have finalised their intended commitments at this stage and so it is still too early to give a final percentage.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 21 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the age pension is now locked in to increase with the CPI and to stay at 25 per cent of the Male Total Average Weekly Earnings (MTAWE).
(2) Has he publicly raised the idea of linking politicians' base pay to 50 per cent of the salary of Federal Court Judges.
(3) On what basis is his suggested pay rise for Members of Parliament justified.
(4) Will the Government consider linking pay rises for Members of Parliament to increases in the age pension and MTAWE; if not why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Pensions are increased in line with the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and benchmarked to Male Total Average Weekly Earnings (MTAWE) on 20 March and 20 September each year. This Government legislated in November 1997 to keep the maximum single rate of pension at 25 per cent of Male Total Average Weekly Earnings (MTAWE) with proportional flow ons to the partnered rate.

(3) There has been no suggested pay rise. The Government has not yet made a submission to the Remuneration Tribunal on the issue of Parliamentarians' salaries. Any member of Parliament may make a submission. The Remuneration Tribunal is an independent tribunal.
(4) Refer to (3) above.
